perturbation.original_text: 1.9 "ELEPHANT TALK Customer" shall mean any company or legal entity partnering with ELEPHANT TALK, which wishes to offer mobile services in a MVNO/ESP/SP model using the T-Mobile Network and the by T-Mobile provided Hosting Services under the terms and conditions as mentioned in this Agreement. ELEPHANT TALK Customers might include the mobile end-users of ELEPHANT TALK Customers, subject to the interpretation of the specific provision.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.9 "ELEPHANT TALK Customer" shall mean any individual consumer who purchases mobile services directly from ELEPHANT TALK. ELEPHANT TALK Customers shall under no circumstances include business entities or other organizations.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of "ELEPHANT TALK Customer" includes any company or legal entity, aligning with the common understanding of a business-to-business (B2B) relationship in a hosting agreement. The modified definition restricts this to individual consumers, contradicting the B2B nature of the agreement. This shift could cause legal issues regarding the intended scope and beneficiaries of the services provided, particularly regarding liability and service obligations, potentially violating telecommunications regulations related to B2B service agreements.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially contradicts Dutch telecommunications laws and regulations regarding B2B service agreements and the provision of wholesale telecommunications services.

perturbation.original_text: 1.15 "Hosting Service(s)" shall mean the network hosting (and related) services - as listed in Appendix 1 - provided by T-Mobile to ELEPHANT TALK under the Agreement, enabling ELEPHANT TALK to provide ELEPHANT TALK Wholesale Services to ELEPHANT TALK Customers in accordance with its terms and conditions of the Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.15 "Hosting Service(s)" shall mean the optional provision of some services. T-Mobile retains complete discretion to change the provided services.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition clearly defines 'Hosting Services' as a core offering with defined terms. The modified definition makes the provision of services optional and subject to T-Mobile's discretion, directly contradicting the original intent and potentially undermining the entire agreement. This shift might render the agreement unenforceable due to lack of a defined obligation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially contradicts contract law principles related to mutual obligation and definiteness of terms in the Netherlands.

perturbation.original_text: 12.1 Without prejudice to the provisions expressly stated elsewhere in this Agreement, a Party's liability for damage suffered by the other Party, attributable to the first mentioned Party or a person for whom it is liable by law, shall be limited to the following events, and the following amounts:     a)   for direct damage to physical goods (property damage or "zaakschade") or directly resulting from death or personal injury: up to a maximum of *** per event or series of connected events and up to a further maximum of *** for all events (connected or not) in any period of 12 calendar months;           b)   for damage directly resulting from a material breach of this Agreement: up to a maximum *** or *** as set out in Appendix 2), whatever amount is the highest, in any period of 12 calendar months.
perturbation.changed_text: 12.1 Regardless of other statements, neither Party is responsible or will ever be held accountable for any harm sustained by the other Party. This includes any damage done by someone they are liable for.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause outlines specific limitations on liability with defined maximum amounts, typical in commercial agreements. The modified clause completely eliminates any liability for either party, contradicting the principle of responsibility for damages caused by one's actions or those of their agents. This is unlikely to be enforceable and goes against standard practices of Dutch contract law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contradicts the basic principles of Dutch tort law and contract law regarding liability for damages and breach of contract.
